root.tree-val: Ok group, a subtree of Trans New Guinea: Voorhoeve 2005
root.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 2005. Asmat-Kamoro, Awyu-Dumut and Ok: an enquiry into their linguistics relationships. In Richard Attenborough, Jack Golson, Robert Hide & Andrew K Pawley (eds.), Papuan Pasts: Cultural, Linguistic and Biological Histories of Papuan-Speaking Peoples, 145-166. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858835622
root.pub-comments: "First of all, the Ok languages, the Awyu-Dumut languages and three other languages, Sawuy, Korowai, and Tsakwambo, should be united in one group on lexical and morphosyntactic grounds. This group can safely be labelled the 'Ok group' as in all its languages the word for 'water' is a reflex of a protoform *(a,o)ok" (Voorhoeve 2005:165).

Canberra: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858835622
child.pub-comments: …it is possible that it [Ngalum] forms a sub-family with the recently discovered Tsakwambo language, the eastern neighbor of Korowai (Voorhoeve 2005:151)

child.tree-val: Ok group, a subtree of Trans New Guinea: Voorhoeve 2005
child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 2005. Asmat-Kamoro, Awyu-Dumut and Ok: an enquiry into their linguistics relationships. In Richard Attenborough, Jack Golson, Robert Hide & Andrew K Pawley (eds.), Papuan Pasts: Cultural, Linguistic and Biological Histories of Papuan-Speaking Peoples, 145-166. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858835622
child.pub-comments: Healey (1964) was uncertain about the position of Ngalum within the family because of inadequate information concerning this language, and he thought it well possible that Ngalum constitues a sub-family if its own (Voorhoeve 2005:150).
child.geography: near the Star Mountains in Irian Jaya (Papua Province)

child.pub-comments: "The remaining language [of the family], Kombai, seems to stand on its own" (Voorhoeve 2005:149).
child.geography: located between Citak Asmat and Digul (North) Wambon
east inland from the Arafura Sea coast, along and around the Digul and Mapi rivers
